items.title: python-rsa 4.1 dropped Python 2 support but did not add a `python_requires>=3` stanza in setup.py
items.body:
This change breaks users of `rsa` package who are still on Python 2 and who do not set an upper  bound on `rsa` to be `rsa<4.1` (or lower). It also breaks Python 2 users of any other library that depends on rsa with an open upper bound. 

A clean way to fix current situation would be to release a new version: (for example 4.3), using the sources of 4.0 (which are still Py2 compatible), and then release the most recent released sources in a follow-up release (4.4), and add a stanza `python_requires>=3` or perhaps `python_requires>=3.5` (depending on which py3 versions you support).

Note that yanking released versions may cause other breakages  (see for example discussion in https://github.com/hamcrest/PyHamcrest/issues/131), so a fix forward would be a cleaner way to address this.

```
 {         "tcId" : 31,
          "comment" : "prepended bytes to ciphertext",
          "msg" : "54657374",
          "ct" : "",
          "result" : "invalid",
          "flags" : []
},
```

I found that python-rsa (I'm using python-rsa 4.0) does not detect if bytes "0" have been prepended to the ciphertext using 2048, 3072 and 4096 bit keys and it decrypts the ciphertext without error. However, python-rsa detects if bytes "0" have been appended to the ciphertext and does not decrypt the ciphertext.

You can see this behaviour with 2048, 3072 and 4096 bit keys and the testvectors from Google Wycheproof below:

2048-bit test vector:

```

import rsa
from rsa import PrivateKey

import json

"""
{
  "algorithm" : "RSAES-PKCS1-v1_5",
  "generatorVersion" : "0.8r12",
  "numberOfTests" : 65,
  "header" : [
    "Test vectors of type RsaesPkcs1Decrypt are intended to check the decryption",
    "of RSA encrypted ciphertexts."
  ],
  "notes" : {
    "InvalidPkcs1Padding" : "This is a test vector with an invalid PKCS #1 padding. Implementations must ensure that different error conditions cannot be distinguished, since the information about the error condition can be used for a padding oracle attack. (RFC 8017 Section 7.2.2)"
  },
  "schema" : "rsaes_pkcs1_decrypt_schema.json",
  "testGroups" : [
    {
      "d" : "",
      "e" : "010001",
      "keysize" : 2048,
      "n" : "",
```

items.title: Add Python 3.8 support
items.body: It seems to me that there is no reason to this library not to work on Python 3.8.0 which was recently released.

items.title: Remove unneeded coding setting
items.body:
At the top of any file in this project we have following lines:
```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
#
```

I know that this is mandatory for Python 2 but as far as I know master branch is not compatible with Python 2 any more. For Python 3 this `coding` keyword is redundant, see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/14083123/10650942).

Can you suggest some way to send the encrypted message to the client so that it can be decrypted properly over there?


I understand this is more of a python issue than one related to this project but any help is greatly appreciated.

items.title: Secure Request: SHA-3
items.body:
1. SHA2 is not secure enough now. [SHA-256 and SHA-512, and, to a lesser degree, SHA-224 and SHA-384 are prone to length extension attacks,[6] rendering it insecure for some applications. It is thus generally recommended to switch to SHA-3 for 512-bit hashes and to use SHA-512/224 and SHA-512/256 instead of SHA-224 and SHA-256. This also happens to be faster than SHA-224 and SHA-256 on x86-64 processor architecture, since SHA-512 works on 64-bit instead of 32-bit words.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SHA-2)

1. And python supported SHA3 already. [New in version 3.6: SHA3 (Keccak) and SHAKE constructors sha3_224(), sha3_256(), sha3_384(), sha3_512(), shake_128(), shake_256().](https://docs.python.org/3/library/hashlib.html) 

So, time to support SHA3 in sign function?

items.title: [Coded] Adding Public Key Decryption Method
items.body:
python3 code
test pass
```python3
def decrypt_by_publickey(pub_key, data):
    encrypted = rsa.transform.bytes2int(data)
    decrypted = rsa.core.decrypt_int(encrypted, pub_key.e, pub_key.n)
    decrypted_bytes = rsa.transform.int2bytes(decrypted)
    if len(decrypted_bytes) > 0 and decrypted_bytes[0] == 1:
        try:
            raw_info = decrypted_bytes[decrypted_bytes.find(b'\x00')+1:]
        except Exception as e:
            raise e
        return raw_info
    return b''

```

items.title: cli Exception TypeError in Python3
items.body:
in `cli.py`, there're some code like `sys.stdout.write(data)`

but in python3, exception occurs:

```
TypeError: write() argument must be str, not bytes
```

So, for better support python3, it's should be changed to 

```
sys.stdout.write(data.decode())
```

or

```
sys.stdout.write(repr(outdata)) #if outdata cannot be displayed as utf-8
```

----

besides, the input also should be changed from str to bytes:

```
class EncryptOperation(CryptoOperation):
    #...
    def perform_operation(self, indata, pub_key, cli_args=None):
        return rsa.encrypt(bytes(indata,encoding='utf-8'), pub_key)
```

items.title: Expose function to find the hash method of a signature
items.body:
It would be great to expose a function that returns the hash method used in a signature. For example, we would like to enforce our customer's use of strong hash methods.

From https://github.com/sybrenstuvel/python-rsa/blob/master/rsa/pkcs1.py#L300:

```
def find_method_hash(signature, pub_key):
    keylength = common.byte_size(pub_key.n)
    encrypted = transform.bytes2int(signature)
    decrypted = core.decrypt_int(encrypted, pub_key.e, pub_key.n)
    clearsig = transform.int2bytes(decrypted, keylength)

    return _find_method_hash(clearsig)
```

items.title: Blinding is broken and incomplete
items.body:
#19 was not fixed by 2310b34bdb530e0bad793d42f589c9f848ff181b

First, blinding seems only to be used in PKCS 1.5 decryption. It should be used everywhere a private key is used, including signing. The best way to implement this IMHO would be to standardize all code to use the same function when doing a `pow` with a secret value, and do blinding there.

Second... 4134431? Blinding only works against side-channels if it's done with a random value. (And not [this](https://xkcd.com/221/) kind of random.)

items.title: Please add per-file licenses
items.body:
Originally reported by: **petrcermak (Bitbucket: [petrcermak](http://bitbucket.org/petrcermak), GitHub: [petrcermak](http://github.com/petrcermak))**

---

The Chromium project (www.chromium.org) pulls in rsa indirectly through the catapult (https://github.com/catapult-project/catapult/) and gsutil (https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gsutil) source repositories. In order for Chromium to be pulled into various Linux source distributions there's a requirement that all of the third party files pass the Linux <tt>licensecheck</tt> utility. Currently there are many files in the rsa repository missing per-file licenses. From a current run of <tt>licensecheck</tt>, they are:

```
$ licensecheck -r . | grep "No copyright"
./tests/test_transform.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_integers.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_compat.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/py2kconstants.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_common.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/py3kconstants.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_pkcs1.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_bigfile.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_pem.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_strings.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/constants.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_load_save_keys.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./tests/test_varblock.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./speed.sh: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./setup.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./rsa/_version133.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./rsa/_version200.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./rsa/asn1.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./run_tests.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
./create_timing_table.py: *No copyright* UNKNOWN
```

We'd like to ask that per-file licenses be added to these files to make it easier to integrate rsa not only into Chromium, but also Linux distributions in general. Thanks.

items.title: Close Pipes at parallel version of genprime.
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Alejandro Cabrera (Bitbucket: [aldaya](http://bitbucket.org/aldaya), GitHub: [aldaya](http://github.com/aldaya))**

---

In the parallel version of genprime (parallel.py file) multiprocessing pipes are used to exchange data with the child processes.

When a prime is found, the child processes are terminated but the pipes are not closed causing a file descriptor starving when a large number of RSA keys are wanted.

A workaround may be adding these lines:

pipe_recv.close()
pipe_send.close()

After the line:

result  =  pipe_recv.recv()

Or probably a better approach handling the pipes with a context handler.

---
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/sybren/python-rsa/issue/27

items.title: encryptine the same string gives differing results
Vulnerable to side-channel attacks on decryption and signing.
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Manuel Aude Morales (Bitbucket: [Mamsaac](http://bitbucket.org/Mamsaac), GitHub: [Mamsaac](http://github.com/Mamsaac))**

---

After checking the source code, it seems to me that the implementation is vulnerable to timing attacks, which RSA is particularly weak to, specially since the implementation is pure Python and doesn't use C.

Recommended way to prevent a timing attack would be to do blinding on decryption (you do that by blinding the encrypted value, decrypting and then unblinding. For more information, you can consult  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blinding_%28cryptography%29) or PyCrypto's implementation (it has both C and Python implementation. On python's code, bllinding happens in: 
https://github.com/dlitz/pycrypto/blob/master/lib/Crypto/PublicKey/RSA.py#L243 and is implemented at https://github.com/dlitz/pycrypto/blob/master/lib/Crypto/PublicKey/_slowmath.py#L41).

On python3.3 using a new(ish) version of setuptools, I'm not able to install the rsa package.  I believe this is because the setup.py in the rsa package is trying to use an old version of distribute (via distribute_setup.py).  To repro:
- Ensure you have a recent version of setuptools (the latest version env uses 0.9.8, and the latest setuptools release currently is 1.1.4).  `python -c "import setuptools; print(setuptools.__version__)"`.  I've repro'd on both 0.9.8 and 1.1.4
- Either run `pip install rsa` or if you have the code locally `python setup.py install`.

I get this error:  https://gist.github.com/jamesls/ddf1098ae32a937eb589

Commenting out the lines 4-5 in the setup.py that boostrap distribute makes python 3 installs work for me (https://bitbucket.org/sybren/python-rsa/src/c17464ffc4fd4bc947f6caafeb220d15b02065c4/setup.py?at=default#cl-4).

Given that distribute and setuptools have merged and that the latest version of setuptools is 1.1.4, can the distribute_setup.py logic in setup.py be removed?

---

items.title: Vulnerability in bigfile.py
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Sergio Lerner (Bitbucket: [Sergio_Demian_Lerner](http://bitbucket.org/Sergio_Demian_Lerner), GitHub: [Sergio_Demian_Lerner](http://github.com/Sergio_Demian_Lerner))**

---

 There is  a security vulnerability in decrypt/encrypt_bigfile(infile, outfile, pub_key). Depending on the way decrypt_bigfile() is called, it may be possible to do a Bleichenbacher attack.

First note that:
1. decrypt/encrypt_bigfile() does not implement Authenticated encryption (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authenticated_encryption) nor uses MACs to verify messages before decrypting public key encrypted messages. 
2. decrypt/encrypt_bigfile() does not use hybrid encryption (it uses plain RSA) and has no method for chaining, so block reordering is possible.

We'll force decrypt_bigfile() to implements a perfect Bleichenbacher oracle. The infile (a message) is broken into blocks, and each block is independently encrypted using RSA. That means that an attacker can reorder blocks within a message and still create a valid message. Also the attacker can construct a new message by mixing blocks from other captured messages. 

Attack:
1. We take a message with several blocks, or duplicate blocks from a single block message.
2. We modify the first block according to Bleichenbacher attack
3. We add many copies of the another block (unmodified) afterwards, e.g. 50 blocks.

If the PKCS#1 1.5 padding of the first block is incorrect, then the function decrypt_bigfile() will fail fast. If the padding is correct then the remaining blocks will be checked and that will take additional externally measurable time.

I found a way to implement this attack and break the Bitmessage protocol (Bitmessage.org) which uses decrypt_bigfile(). See http://bitslog.wordpress.com/

---
- Bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/sybren/python-rsa/issue/13

items.title: int2bytes generates off-by-one number of padding bytes.
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Gora Khargosh (Bitbucket: [gorakhargosh](http://bitbucket.org/gorakhargosh), GitHub: [gorakhargosh](http://github.com/gorakhargosh))**

---

Noticed a bug in the existing int2bytes implementation when re-implementing
a machine-optimized version.

```
#!python


    ======================================================================
    FAIL: test_zero (test_transform.Test_int2bytes)
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/Volumes/data/Projects/python-rsa/tests/test_transform.py", line 33, in test_zero
        self.assertEqual(_int2bytes(0, 4), b('\x00') * 4)
    AssertionError: '\x00\x00\x00' != '\x00\x00\x00\x00'
```

Fixing this to behave accurately causes:

```
#!python


    ======================================================================
    ERROR: test_sign_verify_bigfile (test_bigfile.BigfileTest)
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/Volumes/data/Projects/python-rsa/tests/test_bigfile.py", line 54, in test_sign_verify_bigfile
        pkcs1.verify(msgfile, signature, pub_key)
      File "/Volumes/data/Projects/python-rsa/rsa/pkcs1.py", line 308, in verify
        raise VerificationError('Verification failed')
    VerificationError: Verification failed
```

The word-aligned implementation correctly implements prefix padding, so 
self.assertEqual(int2bytes(0, 4), b'\x00' \* 4) will pass.

I think the pkcs1.py module needs looking into.

items.title: encrypting/decrypting files that are larger than the key length
items.body:
Originally reported by: **Sybren Stüvel (Bitbucket: [sybren](http://bitbucket.org/sybren), GitHub: [sybren](http://github.com/sybren))**

---

Support encrypting/decrypting files that are larger than the key length. Officially RSA doesn't support this, so I'll have to think up a way to break up files into blocks, encrypt those blocks, and store the encrypted blocks in such a way that this process can be reversed (with the correct decryption key, of course).

An alternative would be to implement AES in pure Python too. We could then use the more common method of creating a random AES key, use that to encrypt the file, and then encrypt the AES key using RSA. However, that'll be a lot harder to build.

I want to support encrypting/decrypting large files, as the previous versions of the module also supported this, and I wouldn't want to reduce the feature set.
